print_settings.Notes:: Print with heat resistant filament, like ABS, PETG, POM etc

description.text:
Heatbed mount for Anycubic kossel plus with 240 mm heatbed and glass. Tried to keep it as low as possible but having still manual bed leveling. With this mount, only about 3mm is lost from printh height compared to stock mounts. Level adjustment requires temporary removal of build plate.

Edit: Added experimental version for 200mm build plate with or without build plate. This is not printed and tried. Feel free to comment if something is wrong with this one

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

40%

Notes:

Print with heat resistant filament, like ABS, PETG, POM etc

For level adjuster screws, use M3 10mm or shorter screw. Hole is made quite tight, just screw it in and it should fit there tightly. It should go all the way in such way that top of the screw is at same level than surrounding plastic. If needed for bed leveling screw can be turned counter clockwise to bring build plate up from that location

For glass holder, I used M3 16mm screw. Firstly, screw it into plastic nut all way in. Then add nut into base and adjust it's location such way that it is visible from hole. Then install all three on the printer using M4 10mm screws and T-nuts. Finally located heatbed and glass and secure those with 3 hand rotating nuts

description.text: I created this belt fixation for my Geeetech I3 Dual Extruder Metal Carrier as my first project in OpenSCAD as the original fixation did not hold the band tight enough for precise printings. comments.author: Paul2015

comments.text: The way the arm was angled caused support structures to be built onto the model itself rather than on the buildplate, resulting in a lack of structural integrity (to the point that the arm would often fall off during printing). Therefore, by separating the arm from the rest of the model, the final result is cleaner, more precise, and far more likely to be successful.

title: BCN3D Sigma - STIFFER Jumbo Purge Bucket

description.text:
A simple modification on the amazing large bucket created by BCN3D, I personally printed it in ColorFabb XT, which is great, but I found it to be a little flimsy, with some unnecessary flex, that made the cloth support not quite supported, and made the printer heads vibrate more than expected due to resulting higher resonance sensitivity, perhaps it was needed to be printed in a more stiff material?

What I did is add 4 bridges in places that gave the bucket the much needed structural integrity two of which are in the bottom, and two between the cloth supports which made the cloth fit more snugly, and the design still doesn't require supports.

I didn't want to add more bridges than necessary as it will compromise bucket discharge volume, also note that the STL file is large due to the original remixed file is also large (~16mb), with the reason being fillets in the original design having more subdivisions than optimal IMHO.

Printer Brand:

BCN3D

Printer:

BCN3D SIGMA

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Notes:

I don't want to delve deep into print settings, but I do want to advise printing only the top part of this file to make sure that the nozzle cleaning cloth fits snugly into it by dialing the print settings properly (flow rate, extrusion width ...etc) due to sensitive tolerances.

After dialing the proper print settings I advise printing either one at time, or printing in sequential mode if you're sure your print settings are good, building both the Left and Right part layer by layer might result in more stringing.

Please note that only one part is included, you're expected to 'mirror' it in your slicing software to make its counterpart.

Printing in larger nozzles is also advised, I had success in printing in a 0.6mm nozzle, I also heard success stories with a 1.0mm nozzle, printing with a 0.4mm nozzle will make printing unnecessarily long.

title: Plastic guides for 2002 Freelander rear side electric windows

description.text:
Not too long ago we had one of the plastic guides break on the car, one of those things where we couldn't just buy the piece but instead we needed to purchase the whole unit.  
A few days later I copied the good part (in reverse) and this is the output.  
There are 2 guides that can break so I provided both of them.  
If I was to do this again I would slice a 2mm cut up the back side of the guide so you don't have to thread the wire through it as detaching the locking pin and reattaching was a lot of work and I'm still unsure if it will stick (time will tell).  
Depending on your printer you might need to tweak these part so I'l included the native SketchUp files.

description.text:
I've bought a Penny like mini cruiser and I wanted to extend the wideness of the trucks to have more stability.

So, after doing that I had the shoes that touched the wheels during a small turn and it's like a wheelbite, not very good and healthy !

So I designed those very simple pads to make the board higher and get rid of that problem.

I used the 10mm pads for my use but I've designed for you 5mm, 10mm, 15mm height to adjust according to your needs.

You'll need screws with lengths accordingly to the height of the part you'll print.

The holes are standard ones with 40x60mm spacing.

author: NickChung

title: Learning Blade 3D Maker Quest - Bridge Design

description.text:
These are the supporting files for the Learning Blade Bridge Design Experiment.

This Maker Quest gives students practice designing and testing basic bridges. The model files in this lesson can be used to assemble a variety of bridge types, and can also serve as the beginnings of customized 3D bridge designs. Once the students have designed, printed, and assembled their bridges, they will measure them for rigidity, load bearing strength, and the economy of materials used.

The first few STL files are for the spans and pins. We've included single pins and spans, as well as groups maximized for ~ 100mm x 100mm printing area. We've also included model files for a span and pin sliced into sections so students may more easily modify them into their own designs.

Have you ever considered how massive construction projects are possible? Modern buildings roadways, bridges, and other structures can be enormous, yet most are usually constructed from much simpler and smaller components. 
This exercise gives students practice designing a bridge structure using simple 3D printed spans and connecting pins. The model files in this lesson provide a basic starting point for simple bridge construction. However, the main purpose of the exercise is to encourage students to go beyond a simple, triangular truss bridge design, and create their own unique solutions.

Modular Bridge Design Students should identify and download the bidge component files to their computer.
Once the files are ready to print, students should import them into the 3D slicing software. The individual components of the bridge are designed to print within a 110 mm x 100 mm x 100 mm print volume. The components could be scaled, but any changes in scale could affect the fit of the components.
Once the slicing software has prepared the printing instructions, all of the bridge components should be printed and carefully removed from the printing surface. Make sure to print enough bridge spans and pins to build the desired bridge design.
The bridge pins are designed to join up to six spans, with the ends of the pins fitting through the holes in the spans.
Students should attach spans to each side of the pins so the bridge has 2 sides, and a passage for a roadway between them.
After construction, bridges can be tested for rigidity and the economy of materials used. Testing Bridge Rigidity - Strain Under Stress Begin this test by weighing the bridge itself and recording it on the included worksheet. Next, set up a gap for the bridge to cross. Place two desks, tables, or stacks of books a specific distance apart. A gap of at least 12 inches is recommended. Once the gap is setup, place the bridge across the gap with no additional weight on it. Each bridge will flex and deform once a load is placed on it. This deformation is expressed as the amount of Strain under Stress. Stress is typically expressed in pounds per square inch (psi) or kg/mm2. To calculate a bridge’s stress, first calculate the bridge load area. Measure the length of the bridge from the two support points that touch the base just outside the gap. Also, measure the average width of the bridge. Record those measurements on the included worksheet and use them to calculate the bridge load area.
Next, turn the yard stick on its edge and place it across the gap next to the bridge. Find the middle point of the bridge, and use the ruler or tape measure to measure the distance from the bottom of the yard stick to the bottom of the bridge. Record this distance on the bridge testing worksheet. Next, add a weight to the center of the bridge. The weight can either be placed atop the bridge, or possibly hung beneath the bridge if you have string, tape, or hooks to securely attach it to the bridge.
Once the weight is attached, place the yard stick on its edge and across the gap beside the bridge exactly as you did in the measurement with no weight. Find the middle point of the bridge, and use the ruler or tape measure to measure the distance from the bottom of the yard stick to the bottom of the bridge. Record this distance on the bridge testing worksheet.
If you have multiple weights, you can continue adding weights and measuring the amount of sagging they produce. There is space on your worksheet to record and graph multiple measurements. Bridge Testing Worksheet Calculating the Economy of Materials Engineers have many ways to calculate the economy of materials and how cost-efficient projects will be. In this experiment, we’ll use a simple ratio, based on the weight of the bridge, to determine materials economy.
To calculate the economy of material, take the bridge’s Strain amount under the greatest weight tested, and divide it by the weight of the bridge (do not include the load’s weight). This result tells the amount of material (by weight) required for the bridge to bear the strain of a particular load. Additional Ideas Students could design and 3D print additional structural elements for their bridge design. These elements could be functional, decorative, or a mix of both. For example, in its basic design, the bridge has no actual road or railway between the spans. Students could model and print a series of roadway sections that attach to the bridge’s pins.
Students could also design a way to more easily attach a hanging weight below the bridge. The standard 3D pin and span files could be modified with such an attachment.
This basic design could also be modified into a suspension bridge design with two towers made of the existing spans, connected by a series of shortened or lengthened spans and pins to form suspension cables. By modifying the standard bridge spans, students could design different types of bridges. Students could also modify the standard bridge pins with hooks, or other changes to increase the functionality of their bridges. Discussion Questions Teachers can facilitate class discussion about the Bridge Design project by asking the following questions: Two major characteristics of bridge designs are their rigidity and load capacity. What conditions would require different bridges to have different load capacities? What conditions would require bridges to have different levels or rigidity? The basic bridge design in this project used a truss bridge with triangular bracings. What are the advantages of using triangles to brace a structure? In addition to bridges, what other types of structures benefit from triangular bracing? Suspension bridges are another common bridge design, but unlike simpler truss or span-type bridges, suspension bridges use a series of towers and cables to distribute and bear a bridge’s load. In what conditions would a suspension bridge be preferable to a truss or span-type bridge?

A 3D printer with PLA, or another printer-compatible filament
The 3D model files for this experiment
3D modeling application
3D slicing software
Weights (at least 5 lbs)
Desks or stacks of books (a gap for the bridge to cross)
A yard or meter stick
A ruler or tape measure

comments.text: We've included model files for a bridge span and a bridge pin sliced into sections so students may modify them for their own designs.

description.text:
For printers that use a tube to control the filament path to the extruder, this part allows you to put a filament path directly on to the start of the tube. Once printed, feed some sponge into the bottom hole with a drop or two of oil. Push some filament through initially to get the filament path through the sponge started, then push fit to the tube on the printer.

The initial design here is for the original feed tubes that came with the E3D Bigbox. The model is parameterized, so if you want to alter it, the model is online here:

https://cad.onshape.com/documents/b330e72bb16190c87a6fd48a/v/278cd4f5c6f9b81a03eacef7

comments.text: ok. Look at the frame underneath. Are there 4 mounting lugs on the middle section of the frame? If so, get a saw and cut those off. That should give you the little bit you need.

comments.text: Ok Cool I might try that then and print it in PLA.  I was planning on PETG because I plan to be printing high temp materials and I've been warned that heat creep from the hot end could melt the pla that holds it in place. Hi folks
this is a Raumer S mine clearing vehicle from WW2, designed and built as a prototype by the Germans.
Whether it would have worked is another question, discovered by the Americans at the end of the war, yet another crazy vehicle. It could be driven from either end and was articulated between the vehicles but the turning circle would have been quite large. The wheels were 2.7M high alone so that gives you some idea of this beast.
Scaled to 1/100 scale for war gaming, just re-scale to fit
UPDATE No.1
just added 'raumersroundaxle' and 'WheelRound hole' for those that prefer round attachment points.

description.text:
This is a grommet for custom made curtains. Hole size is 44mm, so it works well on 1" or 1-1/4" dowel as a curtain rod. The pictures show the grommet on 1" dowel.

To use, cut a hole in the fabric the same size as grommet2 inner diameter. Snap together grommet1 and grommet2 on either side of the fabric through the hole. They will hold together by friction.

This is a power supply cover for the HP DPS-1200FB that includes two sets of holes for Anderson Powerpoles. This power supply is used for many things in the hobby world, but my use case is amateur radio where powerpoles are the standard connector. This was designed using TinkerCAD

This design is a remix of https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2227372 and https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1621391

NOTE: I have not printed this yet, I'm publishing it here so I can easily share with a few friends for feedback. Once it has been printed, I'll update this Thing with printing information and update the STL if needed. In other words, print at your own risk :)

description.text:
This is a replacement hinge for Marshall Major II headphones. This part is prone to break and the genuine replacement part is hard to find and the price is close to the new headphones.

Replacement hinge consists of inner and outer part. The joint mechanism of these two parts is simplified against the genuine one.

How to set it up:

  1. Dismount the original (broken) hinge from the headphone frame.
  2. Separate the two parts of broken hinge by applying pressure on the thinner side of the inner part, attempting to "slide" it out. It might take quite a bit of force.
  3. Take out the headphone mount from the outer part. Take out the little rubber bits from the inner part of the broken hinge.
  4. Place the rubber bits to their dedicated space on the inner part of 3D printed hinge.
  5. Place the headphone mount into the outer part of 3D printed hinge (double check the orientation) and glue the two parts together.
    (6). The print might require some sanding in areas marked with arrows on last picture. See the note below for details.
  6. Finally, carefully mount the hinge with headphone to the headphone frame.

NOTE: My print had an issue of not being able to fully extend the headphones, due to too wide hole edges in areas marked with arrows on last picture. I had to sand the outside edge about 1/2 mm to be able to extend the headphones.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Notes:

I used ABS because I wanted to avoid brittleness of PLA on the most strained parts around the mounting holes. Other people however had no issues with PLA.
My print required a bit of sanding to fit properly - see the summary for details.
In Fusion 360, using the broken part and a caliper.

description.text:
The general purpose of these designs are described in “3D Printed UV-vis Cuvette Adapter for Low Cost and Versatile Spectroscopic Experiments”, which is published in the open access journal ACS Omega. Link to publication: http://pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/acsomega.7b01310

This particular part is meant to mimic traditional quartz and glass UV-vis Spectrometer cuvettes. In this design, we have adjusted the path length to account for the average error of our 3D printer. Thus the designed path length is 9.5 mm, but the printed adapter has a measured path length of 10 mm and a sample volume of approximately 2.4 mL. This cuvette can be used in most standard UV-Vis spectrometers. We recommend printing this design with a black filament to reduce the amount of light scattering.

An instructional video to assemble the spectrometer is shown below (post-printing) with the materials used listed. Either quartz or glass windows can be used depending on the spectral range needed of the cuvette.

description.text:
From long time I was trying to make a cheap, light and affordable level sensor for my printer but I didn't like none of these found around, 'til I discovered a very good idea on http://reprap.org/wiki/CrashProbe (read it carefully), so... at work!
The results were conforting, so here is my probe; it should works very well (only tested outside printer) with good repeatability (don't ask me about mills, microns and so on...).
It's intended to fit the X carriage of https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2254103 (I'm yet building it) using the belt clamps holes, but it's easily remixable in Tinkercad to fit your needs.
Based on a Hall sensor switch from https://it.aliexpress.com/item/Hall-Sensor-Magnetic-Module-Field-Detecting-Sensor-For-Arduino-Smart-Car-FreeShipping-Dropshipping/653186357.html

Printer:

D-bot

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.20

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Just print items as shown, then cut away the anti-warping plates.

BOM
  • M3 screw 10mm (autolevel arm pin)
  • M3 screw 8mm (autolevel PCB adjusting)
  • 2 x M3 nut
  • a not very strong round magnet from 6x1mm to 6x3mm (Neodimium cube 5x5mm was too strong to work correctly), like these in fridge magnets
  • a metal pin 25x2.5mm (I used pin from a rivet)
  • spring from a ballpoint pen
  • cyan glue for magnets fixing
Instructions

The magnet must be strong enough to stick the arm nut when the probe is at the top, but must release it when the arm tilts.
Pay particular attention to what magnet side fire up the sensor, only one side makes the trick!
Fix the nut into arm with cyan.
Drill the probe channel on the base with a 4.5mm tip.
Drill the arm hole with a 3.5mm tip.
The metal pin (see BOM) into the probe has to be lightly tight, so you can after find the right length; when done you can fix it with cyan.
Screw 4-5 turns of the spring (max length 4mm) around the probe and cut the remaining. This will help to avoid the magnet be sticking to arm when this rises.
Refine the probe (if necessary) to let it slide freely (really free!) into the base guides (bottom round and top square).
Much care must be used on magnet position.
To enable the probe is up to you to find a good point where to place a pin long enough to push the arm to initialize the probe.
As stated on Reprap Wiki, the bottom side of support (not the pin!) has to be about 5mm above the nozzle with pin extruding about 5mm.
Now it's up to you calibrating all the stuff, pin length and PCB height adjusting, to obtain good results as I did.

description.text:
The general purpose of these designs are described in “3D Printed UV-vis Cuvette Adapter for Low Cost and Versatile Spectroscopic Experiments”, which is published in the open access journal ACS Omega. Link to publication: http://pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/acsomega.7b01310

This particular part is meant to enable spectroelectrochemical experiments. In this design, we have a path length of 10 mm and is meant to hold a planar and transparent working electrode like ITO or FTO. A reference electrode can be placed in the adjacent hole and the counter electrode placed in the second hole. Note that the counter electrode hole is connected to the main electrolyte compartment via a tunnel running underneath. This adapter can be used in most standard UV-Vis spectrometers. We recommend printing this design with a black filament to reduce the amount of light scattering.

An instructional video to assemble the spectrometer is shown below (post-printing) with the materials used listed. Either quartz or glass windows can be used depending on the spectral range needed for the adapter.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/iys9YRzFaZl

I was inspired to create this model for my grade 8 math class, and is a remix of the design by Isos, the chain for the smaller square prints assembled and will ensure that no pieces are lost in your classroom! The model is of the Pythagorean Triple with sides of 3 cm, 4 cm, and 5 cm. Be sure to share any models you make. UPDATE
I have added an improved base, that will allow you to assemble into one piece - you won't have to look for the chain or square again! All parts were designed in Tinkercad links included below:
Base: https://tinkercad.com/things/8KCI2BOjPnM
Chain: https://tinkercad.com/things/07GR4EwqWhq
Square: https://tinkercad.com/things/07GR4EwqWhq

Model has been successfully printed in both PLA and ABS plastic using low settings with rafts. UPDATE
Instructions for use with the improved base:

  • Print the chain and square.

  • While printing the base, you will need to use the "Z Pause Height" feature in the MakerBot menu (or similar feature on your printer). Set the Z Position to 10 mm and turn Pause Active on.

  • Once paused, place the chain and square on the base in the correct orientation and resume printing.

comments.author: Munt

comments.text:
This illustrates physically that A^2+B^2=C^2.
The two short sides of the triangle have sides of 3cm and 4cm.
The sliding square piece is 4^2 (a physical square)
The chain parts make a 3x3 square, and can be wrapped around the 4x4 square to make the 5x5 square for the "C" hypotenuse side of the triangle.

title: Guided Spool Stand
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Simple compact spool stand using 608 ball bearings.
Required 2 parts and bearings per side of the spool (so 4 in total).

Clean out the holes in the large cylinders, sand/file both cylinders until they are nice and round if necessary. Push the bearings onto the larger cylinders, press them all the way down, place 2 assemblies onto each other and press them together gently but firmly. Repeat for the other side.
Filament should be pulled from a low position.

This stand differs a little from the other similar ones already on here:
The bearing mounts are 7,9mm across so a little printing tolerance should not ruin the print. Same goes for the hole/pivot (3,5mm hole, 3,3mm pivot). Should it sit too loose, just use a little glue.
The bases of the cylinders are thickened so that the whole part can be printed lying flat without tearing the cylinders off too easily when assembling the stand. And if they do tear off it can be printed vertically with support required only for the cylinders.
There are "horns" rising above the bearing and acting as an effective guide for the filament spool to prevent if from jumping off the stand.

X-rail supports for a Prusa i3. These have been designed for easy installation, rigidity, and implementing an adjustable X-axis belt. The Z-rail to Z-screw distance is 17mm and the X-rail to X-rail distance is 45mm. These dimensions should be consistent with the Prusa i3 design, so these parts can be swapped in easily.

M3x0.5 screws are used to clamp the linear bearings and linear rails. A #10-32mm screw can be threaded into the pulley carriage and is used to tension the X-axis belt. Another #10-32mm screw can be threaded into the motor side carriage and is used to depress the Z-axis endstop.

I used tosjduenfs' cable chain for the Z- and X- axis to tame the wiring harnesses. You can find the chain at https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:34661.

The trays are used to mount a 3/4" wide cable chain support for the X-carriage. More info on that will be added later.

I will be adding more parts as the designs are completed.

description.text:
Don't wear your heart on your sleeve, hang it on the wall. I took emmett's exploitable heart and exploited it by slicing it in half and boolean punching a screw hanger and an LED holder into the back.  Et voila!  A heart which hangs on the wall and glows.  
It hangs by itself with no visible hardware.  If you want to make it glow you will need a 2032 battery and a standard 5 mm (T-1 3/4) LED.  Red filament with a red LED is the usual choice, but a blinking red LED is even better.  But you can make any combination your sick little heart desires.  Try yellow glow in the dark fillament with a UV LED for a special alien glow heart.  If you make one now it will still be glowing strong on Valentines day.

author: Tioh

description.text: Ring / infinite knot

**EDIT: I am currently waiting on PTFE Tubing, which should be here by the end of the week. I'm going to swap out the rubber grommets, which cause a little bit of drag on the filament, with the PTFE, which should be much better. I'll update with the results.

I've wanted a filament enclosure for a long time. I live in a humid area, so I can only imagine how much moisture my filament is absorbing. I finally found a good box for it, and I thought I would share.

Not counting shopping and printing time, the project took me about an hour and a half. 30 minutes of that was just waiting for the silicone caulking to dry. I bought everything from stores near me, but the components can easily be found online as well. I designed everything in Inventor. The dowel mounts, the grommet caps to seal the unused holes, and the dowel clips to put on either side of each spool to keep them from sliding around in the box.

Check out the Imgur album for a short rundown of the whole process.
http://imgur.com/a/ifo0S

I bought the box from Wal-Mart for about $10, as well as a 3/8" dowel for less than $2.
https://www.walmart.com/ip/Iris-Portable-File-Box-with-Organizer-Top/22374211

The rubber grommets are from my local Ace Hardware. I just asked one of the guys there who showed me their selection. I chose the smallest they had, which have a 3mm inner diameter. Something similar can also be found on Amazon, though I'd recommend checking out a hardware store first. I got mine for 23¢ each, for a total of $1.25 (including tax)
https://www.amazon.com/Grooved-Blanking-Grommet-Firewall-Bushing/dp/B00P3FLVS2/ref=sr_1_3?s=hi&ie=UTF8&qid=1501004596&sr=1-3&keywords=3mm+grommet

I used some silicone caulking I had laying around. Fortunately I had some left over from another project because it barely took any to line the top edge of the case.
This is the kind that I had, but pretty much any silicone caulking will work:
https://www.amazon.com/08641-Clear-Silicone-Sealant-9-8-Ounce/dp/B000BD0QAK/ref=sr_1_1?s=hi&ie=UTF8&qid=1501004814&sr=1-1&keywords=silicone+caulk

I also designed the dowel mounts with holes for M4*5 set screws to hold the dowel in place. I just borrowed some from the spare extrusion hardware I had lying around, like this:
https://www.amazon.com/Degree-Hidden-Bracket-Aluminum-Extrusion/dp/B01LWY99IT/ref=pd_sbs_60_3?_encoding=UTF8&psc=1&refRID=H9KQSKWA9MVM8AYVPMF2

I bought a 450g silica gel packet from a Scheels store near me, but they can also be found on Amazon:
https://www.amazon.com/Hydrosorbent-450-Gram-Silica-Cubic/dp/B0001EJIXU/ref=sr_1_fkmr1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1501005537&sr=8-2-fkmr1&keywords=450g+silica+gel+pouch

Here you can download test part of BJD JET.
This is the thickest part of the whole BJD JET set, so you can prove that it will fit your printer.But first of all, check the FAQ section on 3D Printed Wings website and check the BJD JET manual that you can download together with files above.You can get from it extra information about your printer specifications that are needed to print 3DPW airplanes.Several factors have to coincide to achieve good results of printing of our airplanes.Test part should only confirm that you are ready to start.

Don't worry that HERE three the same parts are named differently.It can be confusing at the first glance but inside airplane's full version the STLs, g-codes, and factory files are named consistently in their folders.
.
Rember that if you don't want to print only with prepared g-codes you need Simplify 3D.After the purchase of an airplane, you get STLs,g-codes and factory files.The decision which way is the best for you depends on it whether you have Simplify 3D or not.The printer's specifications are also crucial.Prusa i3 printers are the most optimal solution for printing our airplanes.

description.text: Just a cover i made to replace the broken one that came with my entry light.

RESUMEN
Robot Ren0 es un robot sigue líneas inspirado en el robot DYOR. Las piezas se pueden imprimir en cualquier impresora que supere los 12cm x 20cm de base.

COMPONENTES ELECTRÓNICOS
En la construcción de este robot se han utilizad los siguientes componentes:
Placa Arduino Nano v3.0 junto placa Expansion I/O para Arduino Nano
Sensor de ultrasonidos: HC-SR04
Zumbador
Pantalla de Leds 8x8 max 7219
Servos para los brazos TS90M
Servos FS90R para las ruedas.
Módulo para seguir línias TCRT-5000
Alimentador USB de 2000mAh

Video (time-lapse) montaje electrónica: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=G6cJmhVJQBw
Video conexión electrónica: https://youtu.be/qTbge-eaw2U
Video funcionamiento con App Android: https://youtu.be/9DqD36_Py0w
Video funcionamiento automático:

Portal de formación robot DYOR: http://dyor.roboticafacil.es

Printer:

BQ Hephestos

Supports:

No

¿Cómo se ha diseñado?

Totalmente diseñado en Tinkercad.

Inspirado en el robot DYOR. Se le añade la forma de la cabeza de un reno como elemento de decoración.

Haz tu propio robot: La finalidad de esta actividad es realizar un robot a partir del diseño dado o desde cero. En este caso se ha realizado una modificación del diseño propuesto y se han añadido elementos para cambiar su aspecto al de un reno. Se han usado otras técnicas de modelaje para los cuernos. Se han añadido todos los elementos básicos exigidos y se han añadido varios más.
Curso MOOC EdX https://www.edx.org/course/disena-fabrica-y-programa-tu-propio-upvalenciax-dyor101x

This are parts for LED and Switch Modules for Prototyping Arduino Projects.

remixed_from.author: FilamentCorner
remixed_from.title: Wanhao i3 V2 Extruder fan adapter for 50mm blower fan

description.text:
YABA is an abbreviation for "Yet Another Blower Adapter"

This is an update or a revised creation based on some of my previous adapters. It's a swap in mod for the stock 40mm cooling fans on printers like the wanhao duplicator i3s. This takes a 50X50X15 blower fan. These fans are common place when it comes to being used for part coolers on these printers. Browse the pictures to see how it installs, the hardware, and how it looks on the actual printer when homed.

Feel free to post any makes or comments

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Treat infill and resolution as you would for most functional based works. You do need support for this model. I provided a picture of the support I used and the position in which I printed this part as well. That should give you a good idea on how to layout the part for supports.

This mod does require some hardware, this includes a fan along with a screw and nut to firmly attach the fan onto the part. I made this mod use the stock screws that firmly attach the stock fan to the heat-sink. You can find a wide variety of 5015 fans on various online shopping sites, however you should always check to see if you are running 12 or 24 volts.

1 5015 blower fan
1 M4 by 20mm long screw
1 M4 nut

Like I said in the summery this is based off of some of the previous work I did. You can see that the YABA is tagged as a remix of that work. I would just like to point out some of the differences I made to this VS the previous work.

I worked hard to remove material from the model while still allowing it to be easily printable. This included switching to a one screw holding system, cutting corners literally, and cutting out a few sides with stuff like the parts name and a creator mark. I tried to place the creator mark and the part name in areas not so often viewed.

I reshaped the extension that holds the fan to the part so that it avoids covering the air intake of the fan. This also allowed me to slightly increase or bulk up the thickness of the extension to make it stiffer.

I did not change much on the fan opening other than removing the cutout I had on the previous work. When I created the new arm extension I moved the fan placement. The fan was not actually using the cutout meaning that it was acting as a small exhaust point. This should mean a better fit with less chance of the air exiting through the intake.

This is a simple list and short description area of the files included on this part.

YABA_spacers.stl: This is a spacer to be used with only the YABA_without_spacers.stl file if you have lost or don't have the stock spacers for the machine

YABA_without_spacers.stl: This is a version of the YABA that does not have built in spacers. This will allow you to use stock or other spacers.

YABA_with_built_in_spacers.stl: This is a version of the YABA that has built in spacers. These spacers are the same length as the YABA_spacers.stl file.

diverter_without_spacers.stl: This was designed to help divert air to exit the back of the heat-sink. Was made to work with the version of the YABA that does have built in spacers.

diverter_with_spacers.stl: This was designed to help divert air to exit the back of the heat-sink. Was made to work with the version of the YABA that does not have built in spacers.

YABA with diverter and spacers.stl: A version of the YABA that has the spacers and diverter built in. An all in one print.

YABA with diverter no spacers.stl: A version of the YABA that has only the diverter built in.

A Section where I can post updates and leave the summary alone.

9/5/2017: It's been a while, but I have not forgotten about the YABA. I have added two new files of the YABA with built in heat-sink diverters. The idea being that they will help divert air to exit the back side of the heat-sink. As the norm I have included one with spacers and one without spacers. I added pictures of a print of the file without spacers built in.

7/31/2017: Decided to just try and allow the air out one side rather than trying to force the air up and out. It just moves through the cutout instead. Hoping at-least with this more airflow will get out and the air escaping from the front is almost completely gone. Going to keep testing with it though.

7/29/2017: Updated the diverter with larger openings, this should hopfully allow more air to escape through the top half naturally, the air hear the bottom will most likely filter into the heat-sink hole.

7/28/2017: Placing the page into work in progress as I work on these diverters. Added a new heat-sink diverter for both versions of the YABA. This has not been long term tested as I came up with only a few hours ago. The main thing it does is force most of the air flow further into the extruder assembly and out of the top via the two holes in place for that specific purpose. What could this accomplish? It's currently unclear as I have not had long term testing behind it. The thought is that it may possibly affect the filament feeding, and stepper motor temperatures in a positive manor. Along with hopefully dispersing the air flow further above the X axis. These parts are thin and I printed them at 100% infill.

7/26/2017: Added a picture of the part with the built in spacers colored purple.

19.10.2017: Added configuration.h and configuration.adv files for Marlin 1.1.6. I have configured the files for my new carriage: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2551717 Please change the necessary sections for your printer like Z step per unit, printer name...

30.07.2017: Added source files of whole design as HyperCube 3030 Design Files.zip

You will need 3030 extrusions: 460mm x 4 (X), 333mm x 4 (Y), 450mm x 4 (Z) for the main frame. For the bed (2020): 235mm x 2, 290mm x 2, For the gantry you will need 490mm x 2 steel rods
For the parts that attached to the main frame you should use m6 x 12 bolts and for the bed parts use m5 x 10
Here are some notes about some parts:

  • 3030_Leg and foot: It uses m8x60mm bolt and nut
  • 3030_SquareHolder: Use it if you don't want to use the aluminum ones
  • 12864_Back_Board: It is for this design: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1676899
  • Bed_Support_v1.1 and v1.2: Choose what you want
  • SK12: Print 4 of this design and instead of original Z bar holders
  • SpoolHolderBracket: It needs two 608zz and a 8mm steel rod in 105mm length
  • X _Carriage_Alternative: Use "Seperate Connected Surfaces" in Simplify3d to seperate the parts or you can find the details here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2379178
  • XY_Idler...: Choose which you want to use
  • XY_Joiner: Remixed from here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2192301
  • XY_Motor_left-1degre and XY_Motor_right-1degre: If you are using vibration dampener, you may want to use these designs to compensate the deflection of the stepper
  • Y_EndStop_Holder: For 20x6.5mm mechanical endstops
  • Corner_Led_Bracket: For more information visit here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2164017
  • LMK12LUU_Bed_Holder: Should be mirrored for the other side
  • X_Carriage: For more information visit here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2425642
    Bottom_Plate_Holders: Cut a bottom plate to place the arduino, powersupply, fan according to the dxf file. Than you can fix these components with m3 screws to this plate whereever you want.

description.text:
It's Yet Another Printer (filament) Spool designed to be laser cut from 6mm plywood.
Besides the laser cut parts, three M8 bolts (either 100mm or 130mm), four 606 skateboard bearings and hex/nyloc nuts are needed.

Vitamis:
  • 4x 606 skateboard bearings
  • 3x M8x100 or 3x M8x130 bolts with continuos thread
  • 6x M8 nylock nuts
  • 5x M8 nut


    • Assembly:
  • 1) Laser cut the parts from 6mm plywood
  • 2) Assemble the base as follows: left base part, nut (tight), bearing, nylock nut (loose - bearing must be allowed to move), plenty of space, nylock nut (loose - bearing must be allowed to move), bearing, nylock nut (loose - bearing must be allowed to move), right base part, nut (tight)
  • 3) Assemble the spool by inserting the sprockets (depending on which bolts you're using, take the shorter or longer ones) and tightening it with a bolt through the center hole of the wheel.
    • When I assembled mine, I only had bolts without a continuos thread available, so I had to use duct-tape instead of the proposed assembly.

title: Root 3 CNC X Gantry Panels (Z Panels)

description.text:
A set of printable X carriage (Z) panels for the Root3CNC by sailorpete.
For more details on the Root CNC project, look here.
Updated 8/1/17 - Upper_Front.stl and Z_Carriage.123dx, see Comments.

Final Assessment: After using the machine with the printed panels for a couple of weeks, I have concluded that they are just not stiff enough to do the job. I had to dial down both the speed and depth of cut. They work, and will get your machine running reliably, but it can easily be better. So, my suggestion is to use these to get your machine running long enough to cut some wooden panels, then replace them. - Thanks.

This model is based on the dual wood brace version of the X carriage with the universal panel option. I removed some unnecessary holes and clipped a bit off of the top of the panel to create my version of the front panel. You can if you prefer, print two back panel sets to get the original universal panel set.

I split both the front and back panels into two parts. The bottom half for both panels is identical, you will need to print one Z_Upper_Front, one Z_Upper_Back, and two Z_Lower. Or, print two Z_Upper_Back and omit the Z_Upper_Front. You will likely not need to print the Z_Bonding_Plate

To assemble you will need four smooth 3mm rods 60mm to 80mm long. The rods should fit snugly in the two holes found on the mating edge of each panel piece. Taping the rods into place with a small hammer may help. If you have to do more than just tap them, then they are too tight--forcing them will crack the plastic. It may be necessary to clear out the holes with a 3mm (or 1/8 inch) drill bit. I salvaged my 3mm rods from old CDROM and DVD drives.

As you assemble the remainder on the CNC build, components will be bolted into place which will serve to hold the two halves of the panel securely together. At this time I have not assembled the front panel (I am still waiting on parts to arrive.) The intention is that the linear rails will secure the two halves of the panel. I have also provided a Z_Bonding_Plate model that may be used to strengthen the front panel. Again, I don't think that will be necessary.

One final note regarding the bonding plate only... when I model a screw hole with a nut trap that will be printed in an inverted position such as this piece has, I include a very thin layer across the screw hole at the top of the nut trap. This causes the slicer to treat the top of the nut trap as a bridge rather than an overhang.

Printer:

DaVinci FrankenPrinter

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

40%

Notes:

I printed in PETG at 0.3mm with 3 shells and used a 10mm brim without a raft..

comments.text: [8/1/17 update] The Universal panel does not include the third and fourth holes for the lead screw bearing holders. They are only potentially useful on the front panel, however I found that using only two screws was sufficiently secure and made alignment of all the parts easier. I added the screw holes for the top bearing. Adding the holes for the bottom bearing would have reduced the work clearance by a few millimeters and I felt that was not acceptable. The Autodesk 123D source file was updated and has provisions for adding those bottom bearing holes should you require them.

I created the gears for a busy board I’m creating for my grandchild. The busy board will contain may hardware items and is not intended to be used unattended.

I used Inkscape’s gear extension to create an outline of the gears. I saved the file as a .dxf file. I used the .dxf file in OpenSCAD to extrude the gears. I then removed the finger hole and center screw hole with OpenSCAD. I saved the object as a .stl file. The process is a little more complicated and I may expand on it later.

title: lm10uu y-axis bearing holder for single-sheet Prusa i3

description.text:
This bearing holder allows the standard single-sheet Prusa i3 to use lm10uu bearings for the Y-axis.  The bearings I had did not fit securely in the slots with zip ties.  
As always, I have included the .scad files, so any modifications can be made.  I love it when people remix my designs, so please make it better!

1) Print 3 copies, I recommend support material.
2) Insert lm10uu bearing into the sleeve
3) Use 2 M3 bolts (I used 20mm length) and 2 M3 nuts to attach each bearing holder to the aluminum bed through the zip-tie holes.

author: zennmaster

title: 1.5 inch (38.1 mm) Fidget Spinner Ear Gauges
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is an ear gauge that functions doubly as a fidget spinner that my friend asked me to make for him. It utilizes two 3 x 6 x 2.5mm ball bearings stacked on each other (per gauge piece), and then the two plug pieces fit inside the bearings to make the held piece of the spinner. It isn't weighted on the edges, so it probably won't spin very well unless printed in a very dense plastic or in metal, but honestly, I only made this for the meme.

I don't know the best print settings for FDM because I use a Form2. If you make this and find good settings, throw it up in the comments.

Peace.

Set of drawers for small parts.
Includes files for drawers divided into 1, 2, or 3 compartments.
Drawers measure 50mm wide X 120mm long X 25mm tall.
Overall size is approximately 177mm X 121mm X 103mm.
Minimum print dimensions required: 177mm X 121mm.

Quantities:
Back x1
Drawers (any) x9
Face x1
RailDouble x16
RailSingle x4
Top x1
The drawers and rails are 1.2mm thick.  I manually set my perimeter extrusion width to 0.6mm so that two paths and no infill will get the correct thicknesses.
The RailSingles go in the four corners.  All others are the RailDoubles.  
I printed with black ABS, but I see no reason PLA wouldn't work as well.  I used Crazy Glue / Super Glue / Cyanoacrylate to glue everything together.  With ABS you could also use ABS juice / acetone.

description.text:
These files allow the user to construct a simple (flat) plate and frame heat exchanger. I use this model to demonstrate how P&F heat exchangers work in my chemical engineering Heat Transfer course at Villanova University.

To prepare your own exchanger, you will need to print:
1xTop Plate
as many middle plates as you like, but I would recommend at least 3
1xBottom Plate

The ports should tightly fit tubing with 1/4"OD 1/8"ID, but you may want to use a zip tie to prevent leaks. Speaking of leaks, I have also included a template for a gasket that can be used in between the plates. A variety of materials can be used for the gasket, but I've had success with Parafilm. You will also need 12x 1/4" bolts with (wing) nuts to keep the plates together.

Note: Keep in mind that the material you use to print these plates will determine the maximum temperature of your hot stream. For example, I use a hot stream with an inlet temperature of 40C (and ice water as a cold stream) to make sure that the plates don't warp or melt. That temperature difference is still sufficient to show significant heat exchange.

The general purpose of these designs are described in “3D Printed UV-vis Cuvette Adapter for Low Cost and Versatile Spectroscopic Experiments”, which is published in the open access journal ACS Omega. Link to publication: http://pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/acsomega.7b01310

This particular part is meant to allow reproducible analysis of samples held in a GC-MS vial (ThermoScientific Glass Vial, Cat No. C4010-1). This adapter can be used in most standard UV-Vis spectrometers. We recommend printing this design with a black filament to reduce the amount of light scattering.

print_settings.Notes:: We recommend using supports that "touch build plate only" rather than having supports everywhere. Additionally, while we typically use a 100% infill to ensure water tightness, prints at infill levels as low as 10% were found to be watertight for over 2 weeks. For this print we used black polylactic acid (PLA) filament made and sold by MatterHackers.

description.text:
The general purpose of these designs are described in “3D Printed UV-vis Cuvette Adapter for Low Cost and Versatile Spectroscopic Experiments”, which is published in the open access journal ACS Omega. Link to publication: http://pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/acsomega.7b01310

This particular part is meant to mimic traditional quartz and glass UV-vis Spectrometer cuvettes. In this design, we have a path length of 10 mm and a sample volume of approximately 2.4 mL. This cuvette can be capped with a rubber septum, and can be used in most standard UV-Vis spectrometers. We recommend printing this design with a black filament to reduce the amount of light scattering.

An instructional video to assemble the spectrometer is shown below (post-printing) with the materials used listed. Either quartz or glass windows can be used depending on the spectral range needed of the cuvette.

title: Toe-Guard for Kick Drum Drive Chain

description.text:
If you're a drummer, you probably play barefoot from time-to-time (or all of the time), and you've had your toes slip around the drive chain of the kick pedal. This can be painful if it happens over and over again. With this little device, your toes will never get eaten up by the chain again. Designed to fit a chain width of about 0.35 in., all you have to do is print and place it on your chain!  
Comments and Suggestions are welcome!  
Just ask if you need a version to fit a differently sized chain!

author: stinefab

title: Flexible plate option for micro Delta Rework with heatbed option

description.text:
Flexible plate for the µDelta Rework starting from a flexible metal sheet from Buildtak.

You need :

  • The heat bed option for the µDelta Rework
  • A flexible metal sheet
  • 6 or more cylindrical and strong magnets (longer they are, better their magnetisation will resist to the heat)
  • Epoxy glue

Warning :
I am not working with eMotion Tech, and definitely not responsible for any damage that can occur to your printer if you try to apply my modification.

What to do :
-> Cut the metal sheet according to the PDF drawing (printed @ 98% scale on a A4 printer (yes, 2D printer ^^), without borders)
-> Print the centring parts (Cales palteau flexible.stl)
-> Drill 6 holes (depending on the number of magnet you have) in the heat bed, at the same diameter as the cylindrical magnets. Beware NOT to drill into the heater you pasted on the bottom face of the aluminium plate !!! The holes must be disposed on each corners of the hexagonal flex plate, as close as you can from the centre of the plate, BUT without touching the heater of the bed, again.
-> Glue the magnets inside the holes with the epoxy glue. The magnets must flush with the top surface of the plate. Crystal tape is your friend for protecting a surface from epoxy glue.
-> Screw the three centring parts with the screws of the spacers of the heatbed
-> Paste your favorite printing surface on the flexible plate (for my part, Buildtak or 3DBedFix), and your done !

For unmounting your printed part, fold gently the flexible plate, and the printed part will pop-up =D

author: zulukilocharlie

description.text:
My take on brackets to secure 2020 and 2040-based 3D printers. Based on the measurements of my Tevo Tarantula. Accepts M3 screws

There are 2 different types of 2040 bracket. These are based on the measurements of the Tevo Tarantula's X-axis. One is intended to hold the whole axis support, the other is shortened in order to allow for installation of a cable chain to the heated bed.

The shorter version has an integrated cable guide to help hold the wires for the heated bed away from the bed itself. I had some issues with the adjustment screws from my heated bed catching on the heatbed wires. It prints without support if printed on its side.

title: BlackBerry Bold Bike Clip
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This allows you to attach your blackberry bold to your bicycle handlebars.  The Blackberry slides in/out easily (read instructions to prevent scratching back of blackberry). Unfortunately, the apps I've tried so far aren't very good, but I've forwarded the info to some app makers so they might adjust.  If anyone finds good apps with this, let me know.
I may crete an iphone-4 version of this soon

• First, measure your handlebar diameter. This model is for 2.6cm handlebars. If your handlebars are bigger, or much smaller (less than 2.3cm), this won't work. If the handlebar is a few millimeters smaller, take an old innertube or other piece of rubber, and carve a few pieces 2.6cm wide by 5cm long, and use these between the clip and the handlebars (alternatively you can buy some friction tape at your local Borg and use that).

  • Print in PLA, snap off the ani-warp bits by hand or with a knife (thin little bits near the bottom of the prints).

  • Use 5mm x 2.5 cm bolts (or equivalent), with washers to assemble. You can use some rubber from an old tire between the clip and the handlebar bar to prevent slipping, but it is not strictly necessary unless your handlebars are smaller than mine.

  • Download an app -- look for one that keeps the backlight on for extended periods, otherwise it will be largely uselss.
    • The front clips go between the side clips and the handle-bar clips (it won't fit the other way, but just in case...) IMPORTANT: To add or remove the blackberry hold down the front clips, and slide it into place. Trying to force the blackberry in/out may cause scratches to the back of the blackberry. Other notes:

  • This is my first Thingaverse post, so let me know if there's something else I should do

  • If there's any BB programmers out there, let me know, as at this point I will likely build a custom app for this.

description.text:
This is an electronics enclosure for the AM8 - Metal Frame for Anet A8 mod found here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2263216

To use this mod the x axis motor must be mounted from the front. Doing so will require the operation of the motor to be inverted.

If you are using marlin, or skynet, you can accomplish this by changing INVERT_X_DIR from false to true.

For the stock firmware this should be able to be accomplished by reversing the wire order for the connector. However, I haven't test this and I would recommend updating your firmware if you haven't already.

This case was designed to be used with a fan, and I wouldn't recommend using it without one.

Printed Parts

Frame

The Anet mainboard mounts to the back of the frame. There are two variants of the frame included, one supports a 80mm fan and one supports a 90mm fan.

8/15/2017 - Added 80mm and 90mm frame variants that have mounts for a RAMPS v1.4 board. The initial frame versions may, or may not, be removed at some point since this version still contains the mounts for the Anet board.

Right

The right panel has mounts for 2 mosfets.

There is a cutout at the bottom center of the right panel where the wiring for the left z motor, z stop switch, z motor, z stop switch, and lcd pass through.

Left

The left panel has a mount for a raspberry pi. I am using an LM 2596 connected to the 5v and ground GPIO pins to power the pi from the 12v power supply.

There is a cutout at the bottom center of the left panel where the wiring from the power supply, y motor, y stop switch pass through.

Front

The front panel has mounts for a 4 channel relay and a LM 2596 with the voltage display

There are two variants of the front panel include. One is blank and one has AM8 center aligned at the bottom of the panel.

Top

Just the cover for the case. The round hole at is where the wiring that goes to the bed and hotend pass through.

8/15/2017 - Added a top with holes for the RAMPs power connectors.

Purchased Parts

Mosfets:

http://www.ebay.com/itm/3D-Printer-Heated-Bed-Power-Module-High-Current-210A-MOSFET-upgrade-RAMPS-1-4-/122028782943

Adjustable DC-DC LM 2596 Converter

http://www.ebay.com/itm/Adjustable-DC-DC-LM-2596-Converter-Buck-Step-Down-Regulator-Power-Module-LW-SZUS/232372936877?ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT&_trksid=p2060353.m2749.l2649

4 Channel Relay

http://www.ebay.com/itm/SainSmart-4-Channel-Relay-Module-New-/381276443034?epid=1101510610&hash=item58c5d8d19a:g:cW0AAOSwPcVV1zt5

Fan

I have a lot of old PC case fans around. There are 2 variants of the frame because I first attempted this with an 80mm fan, but the one I had ended up being really noisy. Instead of purchasing a new 80mm fan I adjusted the frame to support a 90mm fan since I had one of those.

Screws

4 M4x16mm screws with nuts to attach the fan to the frame
2 M3x16mm screws for the rear screw holes on the top panel. The longer screws are needed here since the screw attaches the top and sides to the frame.
10 M3x12mm screws for all other panel mounting screws

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

The frame is somewhat thick and can probably be printed with a low infill percentage.

I wanted the top layer of the front panel on the outside of the case so I printed it with supports, but it may work without support if flipped on the z axis.

This was printed using eSun solid opaque white PETG.

This is another fishing Lure I'm working on... this one is a Rattle Trap Lip Less type lure.

I've only tested it with my ultralight pole so far and it was a tad bit erratic. I think it might need a little more weight up front to get the balance right so I made the front area much larger and I moved the tie on point farther back a bit since these picture were taken so I need to make a new one and then test it again with a full sized (stiffer) pole to be sure.

I used #6 Treble Hooks and #2 Split Rings on these.

Updates

7-26-17 = STL's Updated... The sweet spot for balance seems to be 22 BB's in the front section and 8 in the rattle section.

7-27-17 = Tested the new version this morning and it seems to swim great now with the new weight (BB) counts and placement.

If you have any questions or problems with the files or fitment of the parts just let me know and I will try to fix them.

Remember to tip your waiters designers if you like the service.... thanks for looking

The location alignment pins (red) are just pieces of 1.75 filament. The attachment points where tacked (glued) in place and the wieghts (bb's) are also glued in the front to make assembaly easier. I use 22 BB's in the front section and 8 in the Rattle section for proper balance, but you can experiment with different counts or weights if you want. I give the lure a tap on a hard surface after gluing to make sure the BB's in the reattle section are free to move around. I used a generous amount of CA (super glue) along the seems to try and seal everything up better so the rattles don't get water logged. I quick rough sand and it was ready for paint. This one was sprayed with a chrome (silver realy) spray paint and then hand painted.... some glitter in the expoy sealer really added some shine to it. (although it's hard to photograph)

author: royfazenbaker

title: Automated Glockenspiel With Arduino And Servos

description.text:
These are the files needed to build an automated glockenspiel with an Arduino and two servos.
The device is made with tuned copper pipes, a wood/MDF frame and threaded rods.
It let you play multiple melody recorded on the Arduino controller.

Including into the zip file:

  • stl and scad designs
  • Arduino sketches

You can find a complete tutorial, a BOM, a video demo and some pictures at https://blog.lkiefer.org/
